Thanks Mike for taking of your time.

The interesting part in creating a ne=
w media-type such as
"application/console" is that I was considering coding=
 a generic user
agent specialized in that media-type. Just as browsers are =
specialized
in "text/html". I liked that I could use the user agent for my =
own
project and that it can be easily reused by others to provide out of
th=
e box "hypermedia console experience" as you coined.

What bring me to this=
 idea is that the command line agent only need a
small subset of the metada=
ta if it would parse "application/atom+xml".
By example the app:author elem=
ent which includes FOAF information. On
the command line side I don't need =
it, I only need to display the
email.

A feature I wanted to have on the co=
mmand line, was to open the
current representation in a browser. The href v=
alue of any self link
would be pass as argument to the browser executable f=
ile. So you could
display a richer view with a richer user agent easily. Do=
es it justify
the need of "application/console"? I would think yes but mayb=
e they
are some cons that I don't foresee. Such as not taking advantage of
=
the cache by having two media types for the same representation.

I think I=
'll do the same as the other folks for now by parsing XTML on
the command l=
ine agent.

-- Philippe
